title: PTD Today — Media
disclaimer: Informational only — AI-generated summaries; may contain errors. Verify with the original video.

items.title: How AI Empowers Artists. Watch the full episode on our channel now.

ai.summary: Based on the available description, this short film accompanies Season 5 of the Webby Award–winning podcast Where the Internet Lives and highlights the intersection of AI, creativity, and the unseen world of data centers. It frames how AI-powered artistic tools depend on data center infrastructure and invites viewers to watch the full episode on the channel.
bullets: Accompanies Season 5 of the podcast Where the Internet Lives, which focuses on data centers.
Title emphasizes how AI empowers artists, linking creativity to compute and data.
Produced/published by Google; uses hashtags #WhereTheInternetLives #AI #Data #Creativity.
No transcript is available in the provided content.
Viewers are directed to watch the full episode on the channel.
takeaways: AI-driven creative workloads rely on data center compute—expect continued demand growth that affects capacity planning.
Grid and site planners should prioritize flexible power and cooling strategies to support variable AI workloads used by creative services.
Integrating renewables and on-site storage can help manage peak power needs and sustainability goals for AI-heavy operations.
Procurement and lifecycle planning should account for AI hardware supply chains and critical minerals needed for accelerators and GPUs.

items.title: Boosting AI Performance: Networking for AI Inference

ai.summary: Based on the available description, Google Cloud’s Victor Moreno explains how AI-aware networking—via the GKE Inference Gateway and specialized load balancing—optimizes AI inference by using inference-specific metrics (e.g., KV cache utilization, queue depth) rather than traditional CPU-based signals. The approach adds prefix/body-based routing, LoRA adapter awareness, and network-level service extensions (API management and guardrails) to reduce cold starts, improve GPU utilization, lower costs, and sanitize prompts before they consume model compute.
bullets: Problem: traditional networking and round-robin load balancing miss GPU saturation and send traffic to congested replicas.
Solution: GKE Inference Gateway + AI-aware load balancing use inference-specific metrics to identify least-loaded replicas and reuse cached prefill computations.
Capabilities: prefix caching, body-based routing for model identification, and LoRA adapter awareness to reduce redundant GPU work.
Service Extensions: insert API management and AI guardrails at the network layer to validate/sanitize prompts and avoid wasting GPU cycles on invalid requests.
Outcomes: fewer cold starts, higher GPU saturation, lower TCO, improved latency, and centralized enforcement of security/policy checks.
takeaways: Improved GPU utilization directly reduces data center power draw per inference and increases energy efficiency—helpful for capacity planning and operational cost control.
Network-level metrics and AI-aware routing make GPU demand more predictable, enabling tighter provisioning (less idle headroom) and better alignment with power/thermal budgets.
Guardrails at the network edge can block invalid or policy-violating requests before they hit GPUs, saving compute, energy, and cooling resources.
Adopting AI-aware networking requires investing in new telemetry and routing capabilities at the network layer—plan for upgrades to load balancers and observability to realize efficiency gains.
Reduced latency and higher effective throughput can change where you place inference capacity (edge vs. central DC), affecting distribution of power and cooling loads across facilities.

items.title: Where Winds Meet is #RTXOn with DLSS 4 with Multi Frame Generation

ai.summary: Based on the available description, this NVIDIA GeForce video spotlights the open-world martial arts RPG Where Winds Meet running with #RTXOn and DLSS 4 with Multi Frame Generation. The clip credits @DigitalDreamsyt for footage; no transcript is provided.
bullets: Open-world martial arts RPG: Where Winds Meet.
Showcased with DLSS 4 featuring Multi Frame Generation.
Marked #RTXOn (NVIDIA RTX visuals enabled).
Footage attributed to @DigitalDreamsyt.
No transcript available in the provided content.
takeaways: Based only on this description, continued showcase of RTX and DLSS 4 signals ongoing demand for high-performance GPUs — relevant for capacity planning in cloud gaming and GPU-accelerated services.
Advanced frame-generation and GPU features may change per-GPU user density and utilization patterns for datacenters and edge nodes — consider workload scheduling and licensing impacts.
Supporting these workloads can raise peak power and cooling needs; evaluate UPS, cooling capacity, and opportunities for renewables or storage for peak shaving.
Long-term demand for advanced GPUs reinforces the need to assess critical-minerals supply-chain resilience and end-of-life recycling strategies for hardware procurement.

items.title: The backbone of your steam plant’s reliability | GE Vernova

ai.summary: Based on the available description, this GE Vernova video emphasizes the importance of anticipating the remaining life of an aging steam turbine rotor and deciding the next steps to preserve plant reliability. It points viewers to GE Vernova’s rotor end‑of‑life resources and frames rotor health as a backbone issue for steam plant performance and decarbonization efforts.
bullets: Focus on assessing remaining life of steam turbine rotors to maintain reliability.
Highlights the need to plan 'what to do next'—repair, life extension, or replacement decisions.
Directs viewers to GE Vernova’s rotor end‑of‑life resource for more information.
Positions rotor health as central to sustained steam‑plant performance.
Frames fleet lifecycle work in the context of GE Vernova’s broader decarbonization mission.
takeaways: Proactively assess rotor remaining life to avoid unplanned outages that affect grid or data center power availability.
Incorporate rotor EOL planning into CAPEX/OPEX decisions (repair vs. replace) to sustain reliability and minimize downtime.
Coordinate rotor lifecycle actions with maintenance windows and contingency plans to preserve service continuity for critical loads.
Leverage OEM resources and expertise (e.g., GE Vernova rotor EOL guidance) when evaluating options and timelines.

items.title: Rynek dóbr luksusowych w obliczu transformacji | Andrzej Marczak, Tomasz Wiśniewski

ai.summary: Based on the available description, this KPMG ON AIR episode reviews current forces reshaping the luxury goods market in Poland and globally — emphasis on experience, ESG/Responsible Luxury, “affordable luxury,” personalization, and Gen Z’s preference for experiences over ownership. Guests Andrzej Marczak and Tomasz Wiśniewski also discuss market structure (2% of richest clients drive 40% of sales), Poland’s still-growing but fragmented luxury market, luxury tourism/hotels, the art scene, and future drivers such as AI and craftsmanship.
bullets: Shift from ownership to curated luxury experiences and personalization.
ESG and responsible-luxury practices (e.g., eco-leathers, certifications) gaining importance.
High concentration of value: 2% of wealthy clients account for ~40% of the market.
Poland: market growing despite global declines, but geographically dispersed.
Future-facing themes: AI-driven services alongside traditional craftsmanship; luxury tourism and premium hospitality growth.
takeaways: Luxury tourism and premium hotels increase localized, high-reliability electricity and backup needs — plan for higher peak loads and resilient local distribution.
Greater use of personalization and AI in luxury services implies rising compute demand and incentive for low-latency edge data centers and increased data-center capacity.
ESG focus creates demand for green power, on-site generation and storage, and certified supply chains — prioritize renewable procurement and energy-storage integration for premium clients.
Poland’s dispersed market growth suggests more distributed infrastructure investments (modular substations, microgrids, edge compute) rather than concentration in a single hub.

Both flagship luxury sites and expanding ‘affordable luxury’ retail/experience locations require predictable, premium-grade power quality and uptime guarantees — consider tailored SLAs and microgrid options.

items.title: PJM: Reliable Electricity is Our Priority

ai.summary: Based on the available description, PJM Interconnection emphasizes that reliability has been its top priority since 1927. The video explains how PJM works to make sure electricity is available when you need it.
bullets: PJM states reliability has been its primary mission since 1927.
The video provides an overview of how PJM works to ensure electricity is there when needed.
Intended as a high-level look at PJM’s role in keeping power available for customers and stakeholders.
takeaways: For grid and substation planners: PJM positions itself as the regional organization focused on maintaining reliable service — consider PJM’s priorities when planning interconnections or resiliency upgrades.
For data center operators: this is a basic primer on who to engage with about regional electricity availability and reliability expectations.
Use the video as an introductory resource before pursuing detailed technical or contractual discussions with PJM on capacity, outage coordination, or emergency operations.

ai.summary: Based on the available description, Hitachi Energy frames the challenge of modern power systems as balancing reliability, flexibility and efficiency while expanding capacity to support the energy transition. The company positions digital-first power grid technologies as a way to improve stability, reduce downtime and optimize performance across the network.
bullets: Power systems must balance reliability, flexibility and efficiency while expanding capacity for the energy transition.
Hitachi Energy offers power grid technologies with digital capabilities at the core.
Digital solutions are presented as improving grid stability.
Digitalization is claimed to reduce downtime and optimize performance across system levels.
More information available via the provided link in the description.
takeaways: Prioritize digital grid technologies that explicitly target stability and downtime reduction when planning capacity expansion.
Evaluate solutions for their ability to balance reliability, flexibility and efficiency—especially for substations and system-level integration.
For data center power and renewables/storage integration, look for grid solutions that optimize performance end-to-end to minimize outage exposure.
When choosing vendors, assess digital integration capabilities and demonstrated impacts on operational uptime and system optimization.

ai.summary: Based on the available description, resilient industries rely on energy efficiency, process optimization, and digital integration. Hitachi Energy highlights working with customers and partners to build smarter systems that boost productivity, reliability, and sustainability across operations.
bullets: Energy efficiency as a foundation for industrial resilience
Process optimization to improve operational productivity
Digital integration to connect and streamline systems
Partnerships with technology providers to design tailored solutions
Focused outcomes: improved productivity, reliability, and sustainability
takeaways: Prioritize energy-efficiency measures to reduce operating costs and enhance resilience across substations and data centers
Invest in process optimization and digital integration to increase uptime and operational performance for critical power infrastructure
Engage technology partners to co-design smarter, tailored systems rather than relying on point solutions
Frame sustainability efforts to support broader goals such as renewables and storage integration while improving reliability
